channel.title: Computing - Python
channel.description: Hey, so I have a midterm on Thursday afternoon and have been paying very little attention in my Python class. Can anyone link me to a good resource for Python? Some sort of crash course/outline type thing that I could examine? So far we've covered all basic ideas through functions. Thanks, help is much appreciated.

item.title: Computing - Python
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

here’s a cheat sheet for reference. you probably won’t need a lot of it, but you should review the syntax and glance at some of the more commonly used standard library functions.

Read full topic

item.title: Computing - Python
item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7
item.description:
@reyx7 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:6, topic:547389”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=666294.msg4454732#msg4454732 date=1413942795]

i don’t know? python is a pretty easy (syntax) language. it has a metric fudgeton of features, though; granted you’ll probably only be tested on stuff like built in data structures (tuple, list, dict), class instantiation, recursion, order of operations, basic i/o, and maybe lambda functions.

No recursion or lambda functions yet. Apparently a lot of the test is just like “here is a function, what will print?”
[/quote]
sounds simple, i’d just focus on how strings and lists work then.[/quote]
Gotcha thanks. Yea lists have been pretty big.

Read full topic

item.title: Computing - Python

item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“reyx7, post:5, topic:547389”][quote author=t4 link=topic=666294.msg4454726#msg4454726 date=1413940608]
i don’t know? python is a pretty easy (syntax) language. it has a metric fudgeton of features, though; granted you’ll probably only be tested on stuff like built in data structures (tuple, list, dict), class instantiation, recursion, order of operations, basic i/o, and maybe lambda functions.
[/quote]

No recursion or lambda functions yet. Apparently a lot of the test is just like “here is a function, what will print?”[/quote]
sounds simple, i’d just focus on how strings and lists work then.

item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7

@reyx7 wrote:

t4:

i don’t know? python is a pretty easy (syntax) language. it has a metric fudgeton of features, though; granted you’ll probably only be tested on stuff like built in data structures (tuple, list, dict), class instantiation, recursion, order of operations, basic i/o, and maybe lambda functions.

No recursion or lambda functions yet. Apparently a lot of the test is just like “here is a function, what will print?”

item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7
item.description:
@reyx7 wrote:

Thanks. For someone with decent problem solving ability (have passed calculus I and II), do you think I could learn 80% of this stuff in two days? I’d say currently I understand about 15% of this…
